def.dt: :easy to see or understand The other team's superiority was apparent [=evident] in the first half of the game. The truth is apparent to me. [=I can clearly see the truth] Her reasons for leaving were readily apparent. [=were obvious or easy to see] When we left, they were in no apparent danger. [=they did not appear to be in any danger] From the beginning, it was apparent that she was not an ordinary child. It soon/quickly became apparent (to us) that something was wrong. He started yelling and throwing things for no apparent reason.

:seeming to be true but possibly not true We disagreed on the apparent meaning of the movie. He died of an apparent heart attack. [=it appears that a heart attack caused his death] What was the apparent cause of the accident?
:an heir whose right to receive money, property, or a title cannot be taken away The Prince of Wales is (the) heir apparent to the throne of England.
:a person who is very likely to have a job or position after the person who has it now leaves The coach named her assistant as her heir apparent.
